com.barryholroyd.bluetoothchattechdemo.activity_chat

Class ChatServer

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Thread
      • com.barryholroyd.bluetoothchattechdemo.activity_chat.ChatServer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    class ChatServer
extends java.lang.Thread
    Bluetooth communications: send and receive text over a Bluetooth connection.

    This class is only used by ChatActivity, so any reference to an Activity here is always to the ChatActivity. Its constructor accepts an initialized Bluetooth btSocket, creates input and output streams from it, then starts running in the background to read incoming data on the input stream; incoming data is then sent to the UI thread for displayShort to the user.

    A static writeChat() method is provided for the UI thread to use to write data out to the remote app.

    • Method Detail

      • processMessage

        private void processMessage(android.os.Message m)
        Convert the incoming message into a text string and displayShort it. Called by the UI handler.
        Parameters:
        m - the Message containing the text to be displayed.

      • run

        public void run()
        Run read/displayShort loop.

        When the connection is closed, exit the loop and tell the running ChatActivity to exit, returning control to the original ChooserActivity.

        Sending this thread an interrupt won't have any effect. To interrupt the read(), the btIn input stream needs to be closed. This is due to an apparent bug in Android.

        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable
        Overrides:
        run in class java.lang.Thread
        See Also:
        How to unblock InputStream.read() on Android?, stopChatServer()

      • tmpPrint

        static void tmpPrint(java.lang.String msg)

      • writeChat

        void writeChat(byte[] bytes)
        Send the chat message.

        This is called directly by ChatActivity. The message is limited to BUFSIZE bytes.

        Parameters:
        bytes - the buffer of bytes to write out.

      • stopChatServer

        void stopChatServer()
        Stop the background chat server.

        Sending this thread an interrupt won't have any effect. Instead, the input stream must be closed. That will cause the read() method to throw an exception and the thread can then exit.

        See Also:
        run()

      • trace

        private static void trace(java.lang.String msg)
